headline: How is it possible that people give KKR a high rating?   Do these people actually work here?
pros: The health plan is decent. Deductible not as high as other places, the Cigna plan is actually a very good plan. Honestly, that's about it. Oh, and they feed you quite well. The cafe is beautiful and the food is quite good, but there's a catch. Yes, they feed you but that's because they know they get more in-office time out of you. No one ever goes out for lunch or for a much-needed walk. You're in this glass castle for 12-14 hours a day, get used to it.
cons: Zero work/life balance. Hierarchy is everything, it's all about rank. First-class citizens here, second-class citizens there. Also, everything is an emergency. All meetings (for any tiny minutiae) must happen today or this week. Everything is a meeting, everything. It's amazing that people who are so book smart cannot adhere to common sense and debate something over email or a simple Teams chat. Think of all the wasted time. Not everything is an emergency and not everything warrants an hour long meeting.

- Inspiring leadership at the very top and great compensation / benefits package
cons: - There is some discrepancy in ways of working between asset classes / teams with some teams being more crowded at the top (also as a result of lateral hires) which at times can limit opportunities for juniors and general team agility

headline: I have PTSD from my 1 year here
pros: Looks great on your resume...that's about it
cons: Bizarre, extremely siloed and political culture. Also literally everything is a fire drill - zero work life balance. Was hired into a "staff" role with a nice VP title and seemingly nice people, but never could have known how much of a divide there is between "executives" and how much of a second class citizen you are internally.  As an example, we were not invited to any of the optional training or learning sessions, and even sillier things like being the only people on our floor not included in the summer outing or allowed to visit the dining hall (we had a seamless credit instead). I knew within 2 weeks I had made a huge mistake but had to stick it out.  Zero opportunity for internal mobility. I still shudder and tense up at my memories of my time wasted here.

headline: KKR
pros:
Smart colleagues in general.
Free lunch offered in San Francisco office.
Pay levels are decent if you have 4-5 years of experience.
Amazing views from the office.
cons:
Employee burnout due to long hours and face time requirements. This has led to lots of turnovers.
Too much politics at play and meritocracy is a joke. The head of one of the large teams got the job without any prior experience in the area tells you all.
Very difficult to transition into another role. Options are to stay in the current role or to look for another job.

cons: It's a hard working culture, so the work-life balance here can be challenging. Everyone has high standards. It isn't the right place for everyone if you don't really want to work hard and be the best.

headline: Great Company, Hard Work Required
pros: Great company at the forefront of private equity. Extremely talented and smart people working there. Everyone vested in company well-being due to stock awards.
cons: Very difficult to move up once established in a position and becoming a little too bureaucratic.

headline: Hard work gets you places
pros:
- Brand: excellent name, you get so much respect when you say you work at KKR from friends and colleagues
- Culture: its not all talk, you really feel like one firm. Everyone pulls in to help each other no matter which office/country youre based in
- People: smart people that are really nice. Never have I seen such approachable partners.
cons: A lot of work, and not like banking where its routine work with huge loads and tight deadlines. You actually have to think and your input matters so always be aware of whats going on even outside your scope of work

headline: Associate
pros: They have the culture down; and the quality of people is superb.
cons: Know what you are signing up for; you need to pull your weight here.

headline: A greater company for ambitious employees to build a career
pros: KKR has a positive culture, offers support for employees, offers career development opportunities, is a leading brand and generally provides fascinating work.
cons: The work environment is often categorized as high pressure and employees can work long hours. It can also be hierarchical placing great emphasis on seniority.

headline: Project Manager
pros:
Amazing Benefits with a lot of perks and compensation.
A strong corporate culture that takes care of it's employees and is a pleasant place to work since manners are highly regarded.
cons:
Not much opportunity for job growth in the operations departments, only the financial.
Extremely difficult to have a work life balance due to the demands of the job.

headline: EA
pros: free breakfast and snacks, EA colleagues are nice
cons:
culture is the worst I have worked in - there is no  team spirit, lots of silos, Executives can do what ever they want and Support staff needs to work for 5 people, work load is insane, you are treated like a 3rd class citizen, they tell you they don't have money to pay your the going rate in the same moment you book a 18K flight for an executive...., no career prospect
If you want to loose your self esteem and want to get abused - then this is the place for you to work in.

headline: Office Operations
pros: The smartest, nicest and most professional colleagues I've worked with during my career. Senior executives are mostly approachable. Good opportunities for advancement and professional development, particularly for strong performers. Senior management empowers people at the junior level and gives them significant responsibility. Beautiful offices and meals provided. Excellent comp and benefits.
cons: Some offices/teams can be hierarchical. Strong focus on revenue generators, as is typical of most firms. Culture has not yet embraced flexible work arrangements although they are making progress.

headline: Don't Fall For Their Sales Pitch
pros: Beautiful, well appointed offices in great locations.  Great benefits and compensation packages.  Work with very interesting and educated people.
cons: Lack of growth opportunities and no training for employees unless they are at the executive level.  Low morale due to corporate structure of top down management.  Company culture does not match what they say it is and people are belittled and unappreciated.  360 review process is poorly done and creates a hostile environment.

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Great benefits and pay for employees
cons: *Internal co-worker drama and politics are horrible among EA's.

headline: EA
pros: EA's are great people to work with.  Felt like family.
cons:
KKR suffers from what can best be labeled as a Cast system.  Mgmt bends over backwards for the 'money makers' .. (Executives)... while dumping on the staff and assistants.  Mgmt wants to give more work to assistants/staff but at the same time cut pay, cut benefits, and cut OT - however still holding assistants up to the same standard it once did when they supported them/encouraged OT.    Unless you are a Director and up... they will only take, take, take.
**If you want to advance your career here... its best to play the political game... as advancement is not AT ALL based on merit

headline: Miserable
pros: The only pro is during the interview process you meet with at least 10 people and you "believe" you have a good sense of the culture but it is not the case.
cons: Lunch is provided so people generally do not venture outside for lunch. No work-life balance. Staff is unhelpful and distant.

headline: KKR
pros: Flexible timings, Low pressure, etc.
cons: Lack of personal growth,  Sometimes very high pressure

headline: learned a lot
pros: Good to work there . learned many new things.
cons: Salary is too much low. Increment is also low

headline: Great Executives if you work for Credit
pros: The Credit Entity has some of the best executives to work with, very collaborative. Good Benefits and a nice office. The people in the office in SF are the nicest people I have ever had the opportunity to work with in my career.
cons: Be careful which entity you work for as the hierarchy is very political. Also, Director level is higher than VP so be sure you know what level you are being hired into. VP's are not considered executive level management.

headline: director
pros: It is a large company
cons: No room for advancement there

headline: good experience overall
pros: great perks, gym reimbursement, free food, strong investors
cons: political, up-tight working culture (suit & tie), trust fund babies

headline: Good place to work and make professional experience
pros: Nice place to work, nice offices and food is provided.
cons: No one takes their lunch break.

headline: Not worth it
pros: Decent pay, nice perks, global presence. Opportunity to meet great people across wide range of industries. Great teamwork at the grassroots level.
cons: Insane amount of politics, horrible work-life balance, you will likely report to people who you don't like or respect, and you will not be adequately rewarded for the effort you put in. Definitely a "Masters of the Universe" vibe from some senior execs, expecting to be treated like royalty.

headline: Associate
pros: Good pay, though not as good as past
cons: bad work life balance, very political

headline: Operations
pros: intelligent people, great meals, wonderful benefits
cons: no room for growth; no work life balance

headline: Great team, good work-life balance
pros: free food, smart people, great executive leadership
cons: lots of politics, no more than any other company though

headline: Great firm to work for
pros: excellent environment, great people, fun place to work
cons: long hours can be a drag

headline: This was a great company to work for. I learned a great deal there.
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at KKR would have to be the benefits and compensation which were competitive.
cons: There were a lot of new people coming into the company creating new rules and really changing the way employees there were viewed and treated.

headline: Good Employer
pros: A very fun job that challenges me.
cons: Promotions are hard to get, very competitive.

headline: When it is too good to be true then it is.......
pros: Free lunch and snacks.  Money is good and the benefit is great...
cons: The hour is long and there is zero career advancement.  Promotion is based on loyalty, not on merit so be prepared to work for someone who is less qualified than you.  Technologies are in the stone age.  Don't expect to learn any leadership skills from this place.  You are hired to do what you are told, not to be a part of the decision process.

headline: Great Company with great benefits but...
pros: Great people to work with which fosters an awesome office culture. The employees are very knowledgeable of their work so it makes it easier for to do your job effectively.
cons: Management is out of touch with the employees.  There are more newly hired managers than there are actual workers,  so the lower level employees are way overwhelmed and overworked with no promotion.

headline: Very challenging but worth it if you really want to climb the ladder. Hard work is well rewarded.
pros: Very nice offices, good support system (admin and IT support, learning and development programs). The firm sets high expectations for all of its employees so it can be a very challenging environment, but a good opportunity for personal growth. Accomplishments are recognized. Good benefits and compensation.
cons: Work/life balance can be difficult. There seems to be more red  tape since the company went public several years ago. KKR has lost a bit of the boutique/family firm culture with their growth over the last 7 to 8 years.
